content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

From the thumbnail, I see multiple fragments of tissue, most of which are embedded in adipose (fatty) tissue. There are at least five well-circumscribed, nodular structures that are basophilic (purple), consistent with lymph nodes. Several of the larger nodes, particularly the one in the center and the one on the bottom right, show significant architectural effacement with large, pale, eosinophilic areas, which is highly suspicious for extensive metastatic carcinoma. The overall impression is a lymph node dissection with multiple grossly positive-appearing lymph nodes.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, the task is to identify all metastatic lymph nodes to determine the N stage. This requires a systematic examination of every piece of tissue that could be a lymph node. The area indicated by the green box is a smaller, discrete, darkly stained nodule in the lower-left corner. Even though the larger nodes appear obviously positive, it is crucial to examine every single node, including the smaller ones, to get an accurate count of positive versus total nodes. I am zooming into this specific node as part of that systematic review process. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task for this specimen is to stage the cancer by determining if any lymph nodes contain metastatic tumor. Therefore, I would systematically examine each identifiable lymph node. The selected area is one of the well-circumscribed lymph nodes (the third major node from the top). I am zooming in to assess its internal architecture and cytology, specifically looking for atypical cells or glandular structures that would indicate metastasis from a colorectal adenocarcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every potential lymph node on the slide. The zoomed-in area corresponds to the first lymph node encountered at the top of the image. This node appears enlarged and has an irregular, mottled staining pattern at low power, which is highly suspicious for effacement of the normal lymphoid architecture by metastatic tumor. Therefore, it's a high-priority area to examine closely to confirm or rule out metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it is a large, densely cellular piece of tissue, consistent with a lymph node. In the context of a colorectal cancer case, it is standard procedure to meticulously examine every lymph node at high magnification to look for metastatic tumor cells. This specific area represents the parenchyma of the central and largest lymph node on the slide, and a detailed examination is necessary to rule out the presence of metastatic carcinoma, which is crucial for staging the cancer. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoom-in area, I see a section of a lymph node. The tissue is composed of a dense infiltrate of lymphocytes. I can discern some reactive-looking lymphoid follicles, characterized by germinal centers and surrounding mantle zones. There are no definitive, discrete nests or glands of atypical epithelial cells to suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. The overall architecture, while dense, appears to be that of a reactive lymph node rather than one replaced by tumor. My impression is that this particular lymph node is negative for metastasis, showing only reactive changes.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the parenchyma of a lymph node. The tissue is densely cellular, composed predominantly of small, dark-staining lymphocytes. There are multiple lymphoid follicles, some of which have paler, reactive-appearing germinal centers. The overall pattern is consistent with follicular hyperplasia, a reactive change. I do not see any definite clusters of large, atypical epithelial cells with glandular formation, which would be characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific area is that of a reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, the normal architecture of the lymph node is almost completely replaced by a malignant infiltrate. I see large, back-to-back and cribriform glands composed of atypical epithelial cells. These cells have enlarged, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei with prominent nucleoli and a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm. There is associated stromal desmoplasia and some inflammatory cells. My impression is that this is a lymph node extensively involved by metastatic adenocarcinoma, consistent with a colorectal primary. This lymph node is positive for metastasis.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a dense and monotonous population of small, round, dark-staining cells with scant cytoplasm, which are morphologically consistent with lymphocytes. The cells are arranged in sheets and vague nodules. I do not see any evidence of metastatic carcinoma, such as atypical glands, nests of large pleomorphic epithelial cells with prominent nucleoli, or extracellular mucin. The tissue architecture is that of lymphoid tissue. My impression is that this is a benign lymph node, negative for malignancy. It may show features of reactive changes, but there is no evidence of metastasis.
